title: Internet of Things (IoT)
introduction: The Internet of Things (IoT) refers to the network of physical objects—'things'—that are embedded with sensors, software, and other technologies for the purpose of connecting and exchanging data with other devices and systems over the internet.

sections.title: Core Components
sections.content: IoT systems consist of smart devices with embedded systems, connectivity solutions, data processing capabilities, and user interfaces to deliver value to end-users.

sections.title: Applications
sections.content: IoT is used in smart homes, healthcare (remote monitoring), agriculture (precision farming), manufacturing (predictive maintenance), and smart cities.

sections.title: Technologies
sections.content: Key technologies include RFID, NFC, Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE), Zigbee, LoRaWAN, and 5G networks that enable device connectivity and communication.

sections.title: Challenges
sections.content: Security concerns, data privacy, interoperability issues, and the need for standardization are significant challenges in IoT implementation.
